The team deserves and should get the enthusiastic support of the
University sport-followers. Last year, without the financial support
of the Athletic Association, the mermen "took a chance" and put
through a successful season on the gate returns of the meets. Their
willingness to try the experiment enabled Johns Hopkins to remain
on the sport map, not only in the tank world, but in the world of
winter sports, basketball having been discontinued.

ENGINEERING STUDENTS
VISIT LOCKE INSULATOR PLANT
On Saturday, January 13, the
class in Materials of Engineering,
conducted by Drs. Christie and
Kowenhoven, and including the
Senior Mechanical and Electrical
and the Junior Civil Engineering
students, made an inspection tour
to the Locke Insulator Works in
South Baltimore.
About forty men made up the
party. The visit was very interesting and also very instructive from
an engineering viewpoint. Some of
the engineers at the plant acted as
guides and explained in an interesting manner different processes
involved in making insulator
pieces, from the preliminary grinding and mixing of the clays to the
final glazing and testing of the finished product. They explained the
proportioning of the different clays,
felspar and flint; the mixing, grinding and watering; the removal of
organic matter by means of sieves
called "lawns"; the removal of water by filter presses; the pug mill
process to make the clay homogeneous and to get rid of laminations; the molding in plaster of
paris molds; the threading of the
insulators while still plastic; the air
drying process; the humidity drier
which takes about three days; the
burning of the product in the kilns;
the glazing of the insulators; the
testing process, in which the insulators are subjected to 90,000
volts, the cracking of which would
remind a soldier of rapid fire on
the rifle range; and lastly, the packing and shipping of the final product. A similar inspection tour will
be made to the Sparrows Point
Steel Works some time after the
mid-year examinations.

TWENTY-NINE MEDS
HONORED
Twenty-nine of the ninety-four
members of this year's graduating
class of the Medical School have
been awarded the highest honor
which can fall to the lot of a graduate. These students have been
appointed house officers in the
Johns Hopkins Medical School for
the year beginning September 1st,
next. Appointment is made only
of those students first recommended by the medical faculty to the
medical board of the hospital.
Among the appointees are two
women—Miss Susan P. Souther, of
Lincoln, Neb., in obstetrics, and
Miss Erida L. Leuschner, of Berkeley, Cal., in gynecology.
The other appointments are:
Medicine—Lawrence H. Kohn,
New York City; Bernard W. Leonard, Richmond; Va.; Walter B.
Steward, Atlantic City, N. J., and
John Henry Bumstead, New Haven, Conn.
Surgery—Herbert F. Traut, Spokane, Wash.; John W. Ghormley,
Partridge, Kansas George V. Carneal, Richmond, Va.; Edwin P. Alyea, Clifton, N. J.; Robert A. Hamrick, Birmingham, Ala., and Henry
A. Peterson, the latter to be resident house officer in the Hunterian branch.
Urology—Vincent D. Vermooten, Belfast, South Africa; Robert
W. McKay, Sumter, S. C.; James
G. Gay, Atlanta, Ga., and Eugene
B. Vickery, of Dahlonega, Ga.
Pediatrics — Edmund H. Kerper, Pottstown, Pa., and Arthur F.
Abt, Chicago, Ill.
Obstetrics—Elston L. Belknap,
Waukesha, Wis., and Jerold K.
Hoerner, Lewisburg, Ohio.

Comfort, Texas; Robert L. Faulkner, Wattsburg, Va., and William

HORRORS!

Van Dyke Scores Edison for Attacking College Men
Dr. Henry Van Dyke, eminent
essayist and for the last twenty
years Professor of English at
Princeton, in an interview with the
New York Times, strongly censured Thomas A. Edison for his
recent attack on college men, declaring that Edison, while an inventive genius, goes beyond his field
of endeavor when he discusses culture and education.

ENGINEERING STUDENTS
VISIT LOCKE INSULATOR PLANT
On Saturday, January 13, the
class in Materials of Engineering,
conducted by Drs. Christie and
Kowenhoven, and including the
Senior Mechanical and Electrical
and the Junior Civil Engineering
students, made an inspection tour
to the Locke Insulator Works in
South Baltimore.
About forty men made up the
party. The visit was very interesting and also very instructive from
an engineering viewpoint. Some of
the engineers at the plant acted as
guides and explained in an interesting manner different processes
involved in making insulator
pieces, from the preliminary grinding and mixing of the clays to the
final glazing and testing of the finished product. They explained the
proportioning of the different clays,
felspar and flint; the mixing, grinding and watering; the removal of
organic matter by means of sieves
called "lawns"; the removal of water by filter presses; the pug mill
process to make the clay homogeneous and to get rid of laminations; the molding in plaster of
paris molds; the threading of the
insulators while still plastic; the air
drying process; the humidity drier
which takes about three days; the
burning of the product in the kilns;
the glazing of the insulators; the
testing process, in which the insulators are subjected to 90,000
volts, the cracking of which would
remind a soldier of rapid fire on
the rifle range; and lastly, the packing and shipping of the final product. A similar inspection tour will
be made to the Sparrows Point
Steel Works some time after the
mid-year examinations.

TWENTY-NINE MEDS
HONORED
Twenty-nine of the ninety-four
members of this year's graduating
class of the Medical School have
been awarded the highest honor
which can fall to the lot of a graduate. These students have been
appointed house officers in the
Johns Hopkins Medical School for
the year beginning September 1st,
next. Appointment is made only
of those students first recommended by the medical faculty to the
medical board of the hospital.
Among the appointees are two
women—Miss Susan P. Souther, of
Lincoln, Neb., in obstetrics, and
Miss Erida L. Leuschner, of Berkeley, Cal., in gynecology.
The other appointments are:
Medicine—Lawrence H. Kohn,
New York City; Bernard W. Leonard, Richmond; Va.; Walter B.
Steward, Atlantic City, N. J., and
John Henry Bumstead, New Haven, Conn.
Surgery—Herbert F. Traut, Spokane, Wash.; John W. Ghormley,
Partridge, Kansas George V. Carneal, Richmond, Va.; Edwin P. Alyea, Clifton, N. J.; Robert A. Hamrick, Birmingham, Ala., and Henry
A. Peterson, the latter to be resident house officer in the Hunterian branch.
Urology—Vincent D. Vermooten, Belfast, South Africa; Robert
W. McKay, Sumter, S. C.; James
G. Gay, Atlanta, Ga., and Eugene
B. Vickery, of Dahlonega, Ga.
Pediatrics — Edmund H. Kerper, Pottstown, Pa., and Arthur F.
Abt, Chicago, Ill.
Obstetrics—Elston L. Belknap,
Waukesha, Wis., and Jerold K.
Hoerner, Lewisburg, Ohio.
Gynecology—John L. Goforth,
Comfort, Texas; Robert L. Faulkner, Wattsburg, Va., and William
